summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from July 7, 2020, summarizing major news stories. The leading news item covers the transfer of Ghislaine Maxwell, an associate of Jeffrey Epstein, to a federal lockup in Brooklyn following her arrest. The briefing also includes numerous other national and international news items across categories like protests, counter-terrorism, criminal investigations, and political developments.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: Accused, former girlfriend and associate of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: British socialite arrested and transferred to Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, accused of recruiting and grooming underage girls for Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking ring.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and accused sex trafficker; Maxwell is described as his former girlfriend and alleged partner in crime.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts Giuffre
persons.context: One of several accusers who says Maxwell helped coordinate a sex trafficking ring; she accuses Prince Andrew of raping her when she was 17.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Accused by Virginia Roberts Giuffre of raping her when she was 17, with allegations that Maxwell helped arrange it.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.role: Acting US Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Quoted as stating Maxwell played a critical role in helping Epstein identify, befriend, and groom minor victims for abuse.

persons.name: William Sweeney
persons.role: FBI Assistant Director in Charge (New York City)
persons.context: Commented on Maxwell living a life of privilege in New Hampshire while her victims lived with trauma.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Communicated with prosecutors regarding Maxwell's bail hearing schedule.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Filed a court document stating Maxwell agreed to waive her physical presence for her court appearance.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in Maxwell's case; asked attorneys if Maxwell wished to waive her right to be physically present in court.

persons.name: Francey Hakes
persons.context: Predicted on Fox News that Maxwell will plead guilty and start cooperating soon, facing a 10-year mandatory minimum sentence.

persons.name: Christina Oxenberg
persons.context: Expressed gratitude for Maxwell's arrest, claiming Epstein was Maxwell's boss, not her boyfriend.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in multiple news items, including comments on sports team names, COVID-19, and various political matters.

persons.name: Kayleigh McEnany
persons.context: Spoke on various topics including Trump's tweets, COVID-19, and criticized reporters for not asking about weekend violence.

persons.name: Mark Meadows
persons.context: Made comments defending Trump, discussing federal resources for law and order, and mentioned upcoming executive orders.

persons.name: Charles Grassley
persons.context: Commented on Congress overriding a Trump veto on renaming military bases, called for action from US Attorney John Durham before the election, and announced he would skip the GOP convention due to COVID-19.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's former girlfriend and alleged partner in crime, accused of recruiting and grooming underage girls for him.
Giuffre is an accuser who says Maxwell helped coordinate the sex trafficking ring and arranged for her to be with Prince Andrew.
Giuffre alleges that Maxwell helped arrange for her to have sex with Prince Andrew when she was a minor.
Oxenberg, a cousin to the British royal family, commented on Maxwell's arrest and her relationship with Epstein.
Cohen is listed as a defense attorney for Maxwell, filing court documents on her behalf.
Everdell is listed as a defense lawyer for Maxwell, communicating with prosecutors about her case.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Transferred to Brooklyn Lockup
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was transferred from the Merrimack County House of Corrections in New Hampshire to the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, New York.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The FBI arrested Ghislaine Maxwell at her 156-acre property in Bradford, New Hampshire.

events.title: Scheduled Court Appearance for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Maxwell's attorney requested her court appearance be scheduled for July 14, where she will be arraigned and have a bail hearing.

events.title: Shooting of Chechen Critic in Austria
events.description: Mamikhan Umarov, a Chechen critic of leader Ramzan Kadyrov, was gunned down in a parking lot in Gerasdorf, Austria.

events.title: Albuquerque Protest Shooting Incident
events.description: Tensions at a protest to topple a statue of Juan de OÃ±ate culminated in a shooting where Steven Baca shot and critically injured Scott Williams.

locations: Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn, New York
Merrimack County House of Corrections, New Hampshire
Rochester, New York (site of Frederick Douglass statue)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested on July 2, 2020, at her New Hampshire property and transferred to a federal lockup in Brooklyn on July 6, 2020.
Maxwell is accused in a six-count indictment of enticing minors to engage in illegal sex acts with Jeffrey Epstein in the mid-1990s and later lying about it.
Prosecutors describe Maxwell as an extreme flight risk due to her wealth, international connections, and possession of three passports.
Virginia Roberts Giuffre alleges that Maxwell helped arrange for her to have sex with Prince Andrew when she was 17 years old.
The document is an FBI news briefing that also covers a wide array of other national and international news from July 7, 2020, including protests, COVID-19, and political developments.
